questions.text:
A 10 year old Orange coloured tonsils presents with positive family history of coronary artery diseases. On investigations

HDL=5mg/dL
Tg = 145 mg/dL
TOTAL Cholesterol=80 mg/dL.
Most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


• Tangier disease exhibits an autosomal recessive pattern for its clinical features while exhibits an autosomal codominant trait for its biochemical findings. Therefore, if the patient received both the recessive genes from their parents, they will have an extremely low level of HDL, and If the patient inherited only one gene from their parents, they would have a relatively low level of HDL (about half the normal level in normal individuals) but no overt clinical manifestation of the disease. Heterogeneous parents for the pathology will have a 25% chance of having an affected sibling or homozygous sibling, 50% of having a carrier sibling or heterozygous sibling, and 25% of having a normal sibling, while homozygous parent married to a normal individual will have 100?rrier siblings.
• Mutations have been found in chromosome 9q31, which encodes for the ATP-Binding cassette transporter (ABCA-1) gene. These transporters normally transmit cholesterol and phospholipids from inside the cells into the liver. Thus cholesterol will be accumulated within the cells, which eventually impairs cell functions and lead to their death.

questions.text:
A 20 year old presents with tendon xanthoma on elbow presents with a strong family history of coronary artery disease- with death of his father at age of 35 years .lab investigations are:

LDL=300 mg/dL
Tg = 120 mg/dL
TOTAL Cholesterol=470 mg/dL.
Most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 
• Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an autosomal dominant disorder of lipid metabolism. It is characterized by very high low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) levels due to a gene mutation causing premature coronary heart disease. Homozygous individuals typically acquired disease in childhood. The majority of cases are undiagnosed and sub-optimally treated. Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment are essential in preventing premature death.

questions.text: If glucose is increased 2-3 times the normal consumption and maintained at this level what will happen with insulin in this condition :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

• Insulin concentrations oscillate at a periodicity of 5–15 min per oscillation. These oscillations are due to coordinate insulin secretory bursts, from millions of islets. The generation of common secretory bursts requires strong within-islet and within-pancreas coordination to synchronize the secretory activity from the ?-cell population. The overall contribution of this pulsatile mechanism dominates and accounts for the majority of insulin release. This review discusses the methods involved in the detection and quantification of periodicities and individual secretory bursts. The mechanism by which overall insulin secretion is regulated through changes in the pulsatile component is discussed for nerves, metabolites, hormones, and drugs. The impaired pulsatile secretion of insulin in type 2 diabetes has resulted in much focus on the impact of the insulin delivery pattern on insulin action, and improved action from oscillatory insulin exposure is demonstrated on liver, muscle, and adipose tissues. Therefore, not only is the dominant regulation of insulin through changes in secretory burst mass and amplitude, but the changes may affect insulin action. Finally, the role of impaired pulsatile release in early type 2 diabetes suggests a predictive value of studies on insulin pulsatility in the development of this disease.

questions.text: A patient present with ear discharge and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination shown below Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MRM
Sol:-
Let’s Dissect each option
a. MRM (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy)
Indicated in chronic suppurative otitis media – cholesteatoma
Otoscopy usually shows attic perforation or cholesteatoma debris

b. Myringoplasty
Indicated in dry central perforation without infection
Not performed in active discharge

c. Atticotomy
Performed for limited attic cholesteatoma
Used if disease is confined to attic only

d. Exploratory tympanotomy
Done for sensorineural hearing loss or conductive loss with intact TM to explore ossicular pathology

questions.text:
A non-alcoholic presents with right heart failure , cerebellar ataxia , nystagmus (beri – beri manifestations ) :
This is due to deficiency of  :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Wet beriberi affects the heart and circulatory system. It is sometimes fatal, as it causes a combination of heart failure and weakening of the capillary walls, which causes the peripheral tissues to become edematous. Wet beriberi is characterized by:
• Increased heart rate
• Vasodilation leading to decreased systemic vascular resistance, and high-output heart failure
• Elevated jugular venous pressure
• Dyspnea (shortness of breath) on exertion
• Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
• Peripheral edema(swelling of lower legs) or generalized edema(swelling throughout the body)
• Dilated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding orbital complication of sinusitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ethmoidal sinusitis is most common
Sol:-
Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital complications due to the thin lamina papyracea separating the ethmoid sinus from the orbit.
Topical antibiotics are not sufficient in orbital complications; systemic antibiotics and sometimes surgical drainage are required.
Both anterior and posterior walls can be involved depending on the extent.
Restricted ocular movements and proptosis are common in orbital cellulitis or abscess.

questions.text:
In a 9 month old infant developmental delay , hypotonia and exaggerated startle response . Fundus exam shows cherry red spot on macula . Enzyme assay detects in hexosaminidase deficiency.
Which substrate accumulation will occur in this condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Tay–Sachs disease is caused by a genetic mutation in the HEXA gene on chromosome 15, which codes a subunit of the hexosaminidase enzyme known as hexosaminidase A.[1] It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The mutation disrupts the activity of the enzyme, which results in the build-up of the molecule GM2 ganglioside within cells, leading to toxicity.[1] Diagnosis may be supported by measuring the blood hexosaminidase A level or genetic testing.]Tay–Sachs disease is a type of GM2 gangliosidosis and sphingolipidosis.

questions.text: In a patient who presents with Phrynoderma as shown .what is the next best step in management of this patient ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

• The main symptom of vitamin A deficiency is vision loss and blindness.
• Vision loss often begins as a problem adjusting to seeing in the dark, or night blindness. People with night blindness do not see well in the dark. But they can see normally if enough light is present. As the vitamin A deficiency worsens, the conjunctiva (thin membrane covering the white of the eye) dries out. Then corneal ulcers (open sores) appear. If untreated it eventually leads to vision loss and blindness.
• The different eye signs of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) in children, as graded by the WHO, are:
• Night blindness (XN)
• Conjunctival xerosis (X1A)
• Bitot's spots (X1B)
• Corneal xerosis (X2)
• Corneal ulcer covering less than 1/3 of the cornea (X3A)
• Corneal ulcer covering at least 1/3 of the cornea, defined as keratomalacia (X3B)
• Corneal scarring (XS)

questions.text: In  6 month old infant diagnosed with phenylketonuria is started on a phenylalanine restricted diet. Despite strict dietary compliance , child continues to show developmental delay , elevated phenylalanine and TYROSINE deficiency but phenylalanine hydroxylase levels are  normal.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 
• The natural cofactor of phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), regulates the enzyme activity as well as being essential in catalysis. BH4-responsive PAH deficiency is a variant of hyperphenylalaninemia or phenylketonuria (PKU) caused by mutations in the human PAH gene that respond to oral BH4 loading by stimulating enzyme activity and therefore lowering serum phenylalanine.

questions.text: A man trapped in tunnel for 5 days .what mechanism is the source of energy to brain during this period:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• During fasting, free fatty acids are mobilized from adipocytes and transported to the liver where they contribute to the synthesis of ketone bodies 
•  This process is dependent on low insulin levels, which enhances lipolysis in white adipose tissue due to the suppressed insulin-induced inhibition on hormone sensitive lipase. In hepatocytes, they subsequently undergo beta-oxidation that may initiate ketogenesis 
• Due to the need of transporters for the entry of long chain fatty acids to the mitochondrial matrix, this could be a limiting step for ketosis during a ketogenic diet. Interestingly, MCFA are not dependent on the transporter protein for mitochondrial entry

questions.text: A patient with a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2 DM) presented with: • RBS: 720 mg/dL • Na⁺: 126 mEq/L • K⁺: 4.3 mEq/L Which of the following steps is not used in the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) IV fluid 3% ________________________________________ Explanation: This is a classic presentation of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA): • Hyperglycemia (RBS 500 mg/dL) • Electrolyte disturbances (low Na?, K? requiring close monitoring) • DKA is a medical emergency and requires specific management steps. ________________________________________ ???? DKA Management Includes: 1. IV Fluids (0.9% NaCl) – First-line to correct dehydration. 2. Insulin Therapy – Regular insulin IV to reduce glucose and ketones. 3. Monitor and Replace Potassium – Insulin causes intracellular K? shift; monitor carefully even if baseline appears normal. 4. Correct underlying cause – Infection, missed insulin, etc. ________________________________________ Why 3% NaCl (Hypertonic saline) is not used: • 3% saline is reserved for severe symptomatic hyponatremia with seizures, not routine DKA management. • In DKA, 0.9% saline is sufficient to address both volume and sodium deficits.

questions.text: A schizophrenia patient on haloperidol was responding well for the last 2 years. Now he presented with orofacial dyskinesia, choreiform movements, and possible dystonia. What is the probable diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tardive dyskinesia – Tetrabenazine Explanation: This patient has classic signs of tardive dyskinesia (TD) — involuntary, repetitive movements of the oral-facial muscles (e.g., lip smacking, tongue protrusion, grimacing), especially after long-term antipsychotic use (e.g., haloperidol >2 years). ________________________________________ Treatment: • Tetrabenazine is a VMAT2 inhibitor and is effective in reducing symptoms of tardive dyskinesia. • It depletes presynaptic dopamine, helping alleviate the hyperkinetic movements. ________________________________________ Why not the others? • Peri-oral tremors – Amantadine: Amantadine is used for Parkinsonism, not for perioral tremors. • Acute muscular dystonia – Ropinirole: Ropinirole is used for Parkinson’s and restless leg syndrome. Benztropine or diphenhydramine is used for acute dystonia. • Akathisia – Propranolol: While correctly matched, it is not the best match for the described case, which is clearly tardive dyskinesia.

questions.text: 58-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus(on metformin) and hypertension presents with worsening dyspnea and fatigue. Echocardiography reveals left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. Which of the following antidiabetic drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Empagliflozin ________________________________________ Explanation: This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), evidenced by an LVEF of 35%. Among antidiabetic drugs: ? Empagliflozin: • An SGLT2 inhibitor • Shown to reduce cardiovascular mortality and hospitalizations due to heart failure • Beneficial for patients with both T2DM and HFrEF ________________________________________ ?? Why not the others? • Pioglitazone: o A thiazolidinedione that causes fluid retention, which can worsen heart failure • Saxagliptin: o A DPP-4 inhibitor associated with an increased risk of heart failure hospitalization • Glibenclamide: o A sulfonylurea with no cardiovascular benefit and a higher risk of hypoglycemia

questions.text: An HIV positive pregnant female presented to the hospital in the third trimester. Her viral load was 1200 copies/mL, and she was started immediately on antiretroviral therapy. She gave birth to a healthy baby at 38 weeks by normal vaginal delivery. The baby is kept on exclusive breastfeeding. What is the most appropriate prophylaxis for the newborn?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Zidovudine plus Nevirapine for 12 weeks and continue breastfeeding ________________________________________ Explanation: This case involves: • Late diagnosis of HIV (in the third trimester) • Elevated viral load at delivery (>1000 copies/mL) • Normal vaginal delivery • Exclusive breastfeeding ________________________________________ Risk Category: According to WHO and national guidelines (e.g. NACO/CDC), this newborn is considered high risk for vertical HIV transmission because: • Mother was diagnosed late • Viral load at delivery was >1000 copies/mL • Breastfeeding is planned ________________________________________ Prophylaxis for High-Risk Infants: ?? Dual antiretroviral prophylaxis for 12 weeks is recommended. • Nevirapine + Zidovudine for 12 weeks • Breastfeeding should be continued with prophylaxis ________________________________________ Why not the others? • A. Nevirapine for 6 weeks: Suitable only for low-risk infants. • B. Dual drugs for 6 weeks: Duration inadequate for high-risk infants. • C. Nevirapine alone for 12 weeks: Monotherapy is suboptimal for high-risk exposure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with migraine was started on sumatriptan. She has no comorbidities but has a positive family history of coronary artery disease. After the first dose, she developed chest tightness. She is now planned for migraine prophylaxis. Which of the following is an appropriate drug for migraine prophylaxis in this patient? Options:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Topiramate ________________________________________ Explanation: This patient experienced chest tightness after using sumatriptan, which raises concern for coronary vasospasm—a known adverse effect of triptans, especially in those with a family history of coronary artery disease. Now that migraine prophylaxis is planned, the best choice is: Topiramate: • An antiepileptic used for migraine prophylaxis • Effective and does not have vasoconstrictive properties • Safe in patients with cardiovascular risk ________________________________________ Why the others are incorrect: • A. Propranolol – Effective for migraine prevention – But used with caution in patients with asthma, bradycardia, or potential cardiac conduction issues – Not preferred here due to chest symptoms possibly linked to cardiac etiology • C. Naratriptan – Another triptan (like sumatriptan) – Also causes vasoconstriction, contraindicated after chest symptoms • D. Ergotamine – Strong vasoconstrictor, contraindicated in patients with coronary risk

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of severe eosinophilic asthma continues to experience frequent exacerbations despite being on high-dose inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta-agonists. Her blood eosinophil count is significantly elevated. The pulmonologist decides to start her on benralizumab as an add-on therapy. Benralizumab acts by targeting which of the following interleukins?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Interleukin-5 Explanation: Benralizumab is a monoclonal antibody used as an add-on therapy for severe eosinophilic asthma. It works by: • Targeting the IL-5 receptor alpha (IL-5R?) on eosinophils and basophils • Inducing antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC), leading to eosinophil depletion ________________________________________ Role of IL-5: • IL-5 is a key cytokine involved in the growth, differentiation, recruitment, and survival of eosinophils. • Elevated eosinophil levels are associated with severe eosinophilic asthma and EGPA (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). ________________________________________ Why not the others? • TNF-?: Targeted in autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, IBD); not asthma-specific. • Interleukin-4: Targeted by Dupilumab, useful in allergic asthma, not eosinophilic asthma. • IL-13 Blockers- Lebrikizumab and Tralokinumab

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma after presenting with episodic headache, palpitations, and hypertension. Imaging confirms an adrenal mass, and he is scheduled for surgical resection. Which of the following drugs is used preoperatively to control blood pressure in such a case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Phenoxybenzamine Explanation: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor, usually of the adrenal medulla, which leads to severe hypertension due to excess epinephrine and norepinephrine. Preoperative management: • The key goal before surgical resection is to control hypertension and volume status. • The first-line preoperative drug is Phenoxybenzamine, a non-selective, irreversible alpha-adrenergic blocker. • It helps in controlling the hypertension by blocking alpha-1 receptors, leading to vasodilation and prevention of intraoperative hypertensive crisis caused by catecholamine surge during tumor manipulation. Why not the others? • Clonidine: Central alpha-2 agonist; not appropriate for pheochromocytoma as it does not block peripheral catecholamine effects. • Aspirin: Antiplatelet; no role in catecholamine-related BP control • Esmolol: A beta-blocker used only after adequate alpha blockade is established to control tachycardia; using beta-blockers first can cause unopposed alpha stimulation, worsening hypertension.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of sudden-onset palpitations, dizziness, and mild chest discomfort. ECG during one such episode confirms paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of PSVT?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Oral verapamil Explanation: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) is a type of arrhythmia characterized by sudden onset and termination of rapid heart rate due to re-entry circuits involving the AV node. Acute vs. Long-term Management: • Acute termination: o IV adenosine is the drug of choice for acute episodes due to its rapid AV nodal blocking action. o IV esmolol can be used acutely in some cases, especially if beta-blockade is preferred. • Long-term prophylaxis: o Oral verapamil (a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker) is effective for long-term rate control by slowing AV nodal conduction. o Beta-blockers or other AV nodal blockers may also be used depending on patient tolerance. ________________________________________ Why not the others? • IV adenosine & IV esmolol: Not suitable for long-term use due to short half-life and route of administration. • Oral phenytoin: Not used for PSVT; used in seizure disorders and certain ventricular arrhythmia

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of bronchial asthma is currently using salbutamol and ipratropium metered-dose inhalers as needed. She reports frequent nocturnal symptoms, including wheezing and breathlessness that wake her up several times a week. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Add LABA and inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) ________________________________________ Explanation: This patient has: • Known bronchial asthma • Is on SABA (salbutamol) and SAMA (ipratropium) as rescue therapy • Now experiencing frequent nocturnal symptoms, which is a marker of poor asthma control ________________________________________ Next step based on GINA guidelines: According to GINA (Global Initiative for Asthma) stepwise management: • Persistent nocturnal symptoms indicate uncontrolled asthma • Step-up therapy is needed • The preferred next step is controller therapy: o Inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) = reduce airway inflammation o Long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) = provides sustained bronchodilation ________________________________________ Why not the other options? • A. Montelukast: Less effective than ICS-LABA for control; may be considered later or in mild persistent asthma • C. Increase frequency of current meds: Rescue meds do not address inflammation, the core of asthma • D. Oral steroids: Reserved for severe or acute exacerbations, not regular control

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is undergoing general anesthesia for abdominal surgery. Shortly after administration of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, he develops bronchospasm, hypotension, and flushing. Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants is most likely responsible for this reaction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Atracurium Explanation: Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that is known to cause histamine release. Histamine release can lead to: • Bronchospasm • Hypotension • Flushing These are the exact symptoms the patient developed after administration, making Atracurium the most likely cause. Other options: • Cisatracurium: A stereoisomer of atracurium but does not cause histamine release, making it a safer alternative. • Pancuronium: Can cause tachycardia and hypertension, not hypotension or bronchospasm. • Vecuronium: Generally well-tolerated, minimal cardiovascular or histamine-related effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) presents with persistent symptoms despite taking a proton pump inhibitor for several weeks. He reports regurgitation and bloating. The physician considers switching to a drug that can tighten the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and promote gastric emptying. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate in this situation? Options:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Metoclopramide Explanation: This patient has GERD with symptoms suggestive of delayed gastric emptying (post-meal bloating). In such cases, prokinetic agents can be used alongside acid suppressants. ________________________________________ Metoclopramide: • A dopamine D2 receptor antagonist • Enhances gastric emptying • Increases lower esophageal sphincter tone • Improves esophageal and gastric motility Therefore, it directly addresses the motility component of GERD. ________________________________________ Why not the others? • Sodium alginate: Forms a physical barrier (raft) over stomach contents; does not affect motility. • Omeprazole: A proton pump inhibitor (PPI); reduces acid, but no prokinetic effect. • Vonoprazan: A potassium-competitive acid blocker (P-CAB); again, acid suppression only, no effect on motility.

choices.text: Start BPaLM regimen for 6 months and follow up for immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS)
Start HEZ plus levofloxacin for 9 months and monitor for optic neuritis
Start HEZ plus linezolid for 9 months and monitor for hepatotoxicity
Start kanamycin-based MDR regimen for 20 months and continue ART without interruption

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, newly diagnosed with HIV infection, presents with low-grade fever, productive cough, and weight loss. Sputum GeneXpert reveals Mycobacterium tuberculosis with rifampicin resistance. He is not yet started on ART. His CD4 count is 110 cells/mm³. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Start BPaLM regimen for 6 months and follow up for immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) ________________________________________ Explanation: This patient has: • HIV infection with a low CD4 count (110 cells/mm³) • Rifampicin-resistant TB (RR-TB) confirmed on GeneXpert • No current ART ________________________________________ Management Overview: For HIV patients with RR-TB, the WHO recommends a short-course all-oral regimen like BPaLM, which includes: • Bedaquiline • Pa Pretomanid • Linezolid • Moxifloxacin Duration: 6 months, extendable to 9 months in certain cases. This regimen is preferred due to: • High efficacy • Avoidance of injectable agents (which are more toxic) • Compatibility with ART initiation ________________________________________ IRIS Consideration: Since the patient has a low CD4 count, starting ART can trigger Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) — a paradoxical worsening of TB symptoms due to immune recovery. Hence, close monitoring is required. ________________________________________ Why not the others? • B. HEZ + levofloxacin: Not a WHO-recommended MDR regimen; levofloxacin is a second-line agent, but this combo is incomplete. • C. HEZ + linezolid: Inadequate for RR/MDR-TB. • D. Kanamycin-based MDR regimen: Injectable-based regimens are outdated due to toxicity and lower efficacy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male undergoing surgery under general anesthesia with sevoflurane and succinylcholine develops rapidly increasing body temperature, muscle rigidity, tachycardia, and metabolic acidosis shortly after induction. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dantrolene Explanation: This patient is showing signs of malignant hyperthermia (MH), a rare but life-threatening condition triggered by certain anesthetics (like sevoflurane) and succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals. Key features of MH: • Rapidly increasing body temperature (hyperthermia) • Muscle rigidity • Tachycardia • Metabolic (lactic) acidosis • Elevated CO? and rhabdomyolysis ________________________________________ Treatment of Choice: Dantrolene • Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant that acts by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells. • This reduces muscle rigidity and heat production. • It's life-saving and should be administered immediately in suspected cases. ________________________________________ Why not the others? • Diazepam: A benzodiazepine used for seizures or anxiety, not effective in MH. • Paracetamol: Antipyretic, but insufficient for the hyperthermia in MH. • Propranolol: A beta-blocker; may address tachycardia but does not treat the underlying cause.

questions.text: Histological examination of a neck tumor shows tumor cells positive for synaptophysin, Chromogranin, TTF-1 and there is amyloid material deposited in the tissue. What is likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Presence of amyloid in a neck tumor is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is also positive for Chromogranin, synaptophysi.

questions.text: CD markers can be detected by which of the following test
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Flow cytometry is used for assessing CD markers.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic kidney disease presents to the OPD with paleness, progressive dyspnea, and signs of congestive cardiac failure. His lab results show a normocytic normochromic anemia. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Darbepoetin alfa ________________________________________ Explanation: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) often develop anemia due to decreased production of erythropoietin by the kidneys. This leads to: • Normocytic normochromic anemia (as described in the question) • Symptoms like fatigue, dyspnea, and signs of cardiac strain ________________________________________ Darbepoetin alfa: • A long-acting erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) • Stimulates red blood cell production • Mainstay treatment for anemia in CKD ________________________________________ Why not the others? • Parenteral/Oral Iron: Only appropriate if iron deficiency is documented (typically causes microcytic anemia). • Filgrastim- CSR for treatment of neurtopenia

questions.text: 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He has a fever of 102°F for the past few hours, and this is his first seizure episode. He is not on any medications and has no past history of seizures or neurological illness. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diazepam ________________________________________ Explanation: This child is presenting with a first episode of febrile seizure, which is common between 6 months and 5 years of age, typically triggered by fever. ________________________________________ Immediate management: • If the seizure is ongoing (generalized tonic-clonic), the first-line treatment is benzodiazepines to abort the seizure. • Diazepam (IV or rectal) is preferred in emergency settings for rapid seizure control. ________________________________________ Why not the others? • Phenytoin: Used in status epilepticus or recurrent seizures, not first-line for single febrile seizure. • Valproate: Used for seizure prophylaxis, not emergency termination. Ethosuximide: Used for absence seizures, not febrile ones.

questions.text: Histological examination of lung shows pink frothy material and hemosiderin laden macrophages. Which of the following is not likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hhistological description is suggestive of pulmonary edema, option A does not cause pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Patient has history of cough and respiratory discomfort for 1 month and hilar lymphadenopathy, biopsy shows granulomas with Stellate inclusions what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stellate lesions are nothing but description of asteroid bodies which are star shaped inclusions within granulomas seen in sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate from elderly male patient having recurrent infections, bleeding, BMA shows 25% blasts as below, what translocation is likely to be seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) BM shows blasts with multiple auer rods which are seen in acute promyelocytic leukaemia, which shows t(15;17)

questions.text: A patient on some medications complains of oral lesionand(purple colour) has been on medication for the last 6 months. He develops a burning sensation on intake of spicy food. Which of the following medication is responsible for it?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lithium ________________________________________ Explanation: The symptoms described — violaceous oral lesions and burning sensation on spicy food intake — are characteristic of oral lichen planus, a condition that can be drug-induced. Lithium is a well-known drug that can induce or exacerbate lichen planus, particularly oral lichen planus, presenting as: • Violaceous, flat-topped lesions • Burning pain, especially with spicy or acidic foods • Chronic discomfort in the oral mucosa ________________________________________ Why not the others? • Beta blocker: Rarely associated with lichen planus but more commonly causes other cutaneous side effects. • Ciprofloxacin: Can cause photosensitivity and tendinitis but not typically oral lichen planus. • Fluconazole: Antifungal, not implicated in oral mucosal lichenoid reactions.

questions.text: Child presents with severe infections, decreased B and T cells, decreased ADA which of the following is diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Decreased B and T cells suggests combined immunodeficiency, decreased ADA (adenosine deamiase ) is SCID

questions.text: A child has presented with fatigue, Jaundice and Splenomegaly. MCHC is increased. His father also has similar history. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Increased MCHC is seen in speherocytosis, child with jaundice, family history positive (dominant) thus hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text: Chlorthalidone prevents renal stone formation by what mechanism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Decreased calcium excretion Explanation: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic. Thiazide diuretics (including chlorthalidone) reduce urinary calcium excretion, which helps prevent the formation of calcium-containing kidney stones—especially calcium oxalate stones. ________________________________________ Mechanism: • Thiazides promote sodium and water loss in the distal convoluted tubule. • They increase calcium reabsorption from the renal tubule, thereby reducing urinary calcium excretion. • Lower calcium levels in urine reduce supersaturation of calcium salts and decrease stone formation. ________________________________________ Why other options are incorrect: • a. Decreased oxalate excretion: Not the primary mechanism. • b. Increased oxalate excretion: Would increase stone risk, not decrease it. • d. Increased calcium excretion: Increases stone risk, the opposite effect of chlorthalidone.

questions.text: A child presents with visual disturbance. Imaging shows supra sellar tumor. Histopathology shows anucleate squames and wet keratin. What is likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Suprasellar tumor+ Anucleate squames and wet keratin is characteristic of Craniopharynfioma.

choices.text: Hydrolysis of uric acid to allantoin
Oxidation of uric acid to allantoin

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which pegloticase reduces serum uric acid levels?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oxidation of uric acid to allantoin Explanation: Pegloticase is a recombinant uricase enzyme used in the treatment of chronic gout refractory to conventional therapy. • Its primary mechanism is the oxidation of uric acid to allantoin, a more water-soluble and easily excretable compound. • Humans lack uricase naturally, so Pegloticase helps mimic this enzymatic process to lower uric acid levels. Why not the others? • Inhibits xanthine oxidase: This is the mechanism of allopurinol and febuxostat. • Hydrolysis of uric acid to allantoin: Incorrect — the conversion is via oxidation, not hydrolysis. • Inhibit URAT-1: Mechanism of probenecid, which increases renal uric acid excretion.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed of depleted factor IX, the disease got corrected with injection of Vitamin K. which of the following could be etiology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Factor IX deficiency getting corrected with vitamin K means it is vitamin K deficiency. Vitamin K being fat soluble vitamin will be deficient in fat malabsorption ( bile duct obstruction causes fat malabsorption)

questions.text: A girl presents with photosensitive skin lesions BCC on face, which of the following abnormality is likely to be seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) BCC and photosensitive skin lesions are seen in Xeroderma pigmentosa, which shows NER.

choices.text: Start ART immediately, followed by ATT after 8 weeks
Start both ART and ATT simultaneously
Start ATT first, and initiate ART within 2 weeks
Start ART first, and add ATT after 2 weeks

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, chronic cough, and is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. His HIV test is positive. He is not yet on antiretroviral therapy (ART) or anti-tubercular treatment (ATT). His CD4 count is 42 cells/mm³. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Start ATT first, and initiate ART within 2 weeks Explanation: In HIV-positive patients with TB co-infection and very low CD4 counts (<50 cells/mm³), the recommended approach is: • Start ATT (anti-tubercular therapy) first • Initiate ART within 2 weeks of starting ATT This reduces the risk of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) while minimizing delay in controlling HIV progression in severely immunocompromised patients. ________________________________________ Why not the others? • Start ART immediately, followed by ATT after 8 weeks: Delaying ATT worsens TB, which is more immediately life-threatening. • Start both simultaneously: Increases risk of IRIS and drug interactions.

questions.text: A child presents with lens dislocation, tall stature. Which gene is mutated.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Clinically this is Marian’s syndrome which has fibrilling (FBN) mutation.

questions.text: Which of the following disease follows the pattern of inheritance shown below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The pedigree shows mother to 100% children and fac=ther to 0% transmission which is seen in mitochondrial and option A is mitochondrial.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy presents with palpitations. ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia. He is hemodynamically stable. The decision is made to start amiodarone for rhythm control. Amiodarone primarily acts on which phase of the cardiac action potential?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Phase 3 Explanation: Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug under the Vaughan-Williams classification. Its primary mechanism of action is: ?? Blocking potassium (K?) channels, which prolongs repolarization during the Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. This leads to: • Prolonged action potential duration • Prolonged QT interval • Increased refractory period — reducing the likelihood of re-entry arrhythmias. Cardiac Action Potential Phases (for reference): • Phase 0: Rapid Na? influx ? depolarization • Phase 1: Transient K? efflux ? initial repolarization • Phase 2: Ca²? influx (plateau) • Phase 3: K? efflux ? repolarization (target of amiodarone) • Phase 4: Resting potential

a. Randomisation,

c. Follow up, 
d. Statistical assessment. Options:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) – ABCD Explanation

questions.text: 70,00,000 population which had 30% slums. How many U-PHCs as per the norms for the slum areas. Options were:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) – 42 Explanation 30% of slums of total population 70,00,000 = 21 L UPHC norm as per NHM = 1 per 50 K Number of UPHC needed = 21L/ 50 K = 42

questions.text: Abattoir presents with Malignant pustule. Mc Faydean reaction with polychrome methylene blue is positive. Choose the correct causative agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B.anthracis Anthrax causes malignant pustule (painless black eschar). Diagnosis by McFadyean reaction (purple capsule with polychrome methylene blue). B. anthracis is a Gram-positive rod with capsule made of poly-D-glutamic acid.

questions.text: A patient presents with an abscess. Microscopy of the aspirate shows Gram Positive filamentous bacteria and positive for Modified Acid-fast stain. Paraffin bait technique for isolation. What is the agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nocardia Nocardia is a Gram-positive filamentous bacterium, partially acid-fast, aerobic, and urease positive. Distinguished from Actinomyces (anaerobic, not acid-fast). Isolated via paraffin bait technique, it causes brain abscesses, lung infections, and cutaneous lesions.

questions.text: Time taken between entry of organism in body to max infectivity:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Generation time Explanation: • Generation time = time interval between entry of infection and maximum infectivity. • Incubation period = entry to symptom onset. • Serial interval = onset in primary case to onset in secondary case.

questions.text: A patient admitted with h/o cough and sputum. Cavitation in lung is present. Budding yeast cells in macrophage. SDA agar microscopy shown in the image. Identify this
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Histoplasma capsulatum Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to certain regions. It causes cavitary lung lesions and is intracellular—often seen within macrophages. On SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar), mold form shows tuberculate macroconidia. It mimics TB and is common in bird droppings and bat-inhabited caves.

questions.text: A female came with the Toxoplasma infection positive 4 years ago. what will you do now
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Continue pregnancy If Toxoplasma IgG positive and IgM negative, and infection occurred years ago, there is no risk to fetus. No need to terminate or perform amniocentesis. Prophylaxis not needed unless immunocompromised. Only recent/acute infection in pregnancy poses risk.

That’s simataneous perception

questions.text: College student with severe sore throat, fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Likely agent is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) EBV This is infectious mononucleosis. EBV infects B cells via CD21. Classic features: posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, atypical lymphocytes on smear. EBV is detected by heterophile antibody (Monospot test).

choices.text: Individual’s location during the enumeration period

questions.text: In the “Census of India”, “de-facto” system is used for the collection of data. This implies that the data is collected for the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Individual’s location during the enumeration period Explanation • De jure census: Counts people at their usual place of residence. • De facto census: Counts people where they are found on the census day, regardless of their usual residence. • Example: If someone is temporarily living in another city for work during the census, a de jure census would still count them at their home address, while a de facto census would count them at their temporary location.

questions.text: A 58-year diabetic patient was diagnosed with COVID-19 and admitted to DHH. He succumbed to death within 7 days. His death was recorded by the hospital. This type of surveillance is known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) – Passive Explanation

choices.text: National nutritional deficiency programme in public health

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with bowing of leg which team is responsible for help?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ICDS Explanation: • ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services) targets <6 years, providing nutrition, health checkups, supplementation, etc. • Bow legs in toddlers is often nutritional rickets, addressed through ICDS services.

questions.text: A 25-year-old sewage worker came with fever, weakness and conjunctival suffusion for one week duration. Lab diagnosis reveals increased ALT, Bilirubin and decreased urine output. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Weil’s Disease Weil’s disease is a severe form of leptospirosis (caused by Leptospira interrogans). Common in sewage workers. Features include fever, jaundice, renal failure, and conjunctival suffusion. Diagnosis: serology (MAT) and dark field microscopy from blood/urine.

questions.text: One new intervention testing was to be done for which 2 groups were formed: 20 for standard PHC care and another 20 for interventional care. What study will be helpful?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) – Cluster randomized controlled trial Explanation Unit is a Group/ Cluster; and there is an artificial intervention

questions.text: A child presents with sore throat. Pathogen diagnosed as Streptococcus pyogenes. Which structure facilitates adhesion of this pathogen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lipoteichoic acid Adherence of Streptococcus pyogenes to epithelial cells is facilitated by lipoteichoic acid, which anchors to host fibronectin. M protein prevents phagocytosis. Capsule is made of hyaluronic acid but non-immunogenic.

questions.text: Compare means between two 2 different groups. Name the test:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) -

Unpaired t test Explanation

choices.text: Inflammation in anterior part of septum
Topical broad spectrum antibiotics is  given to treat
Ethmoid sinus infection is common cause in all ages
Clinical features of proptosis with decreased vision with normal pupil and eye movements

questions.text: Which is true statement for orbital cellulitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pre-septal cellulitis: when infection/inflammation anterior to the orbital septum. Treated by systemic antbiotics/NSAIDs
Orbital cellulitis: when infection/inflammation is behind the orbital septum. It can cause optic nerve involvement and altered pupil reactions. It can cause ophthalmoplegia (decreased eye movements)
After taking blood samples for culture, intravenous antibiotics and NSAIDs.
Ethmoid sinus infection is common cause in all ages as medial wall is thinnest in orbit

questions.text: Mother diagnosed with HIV at 34 weeks given treatment and delivered healthy male at 38 weeks. Mother Viral load 1200. What to be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Zidovudine + Nevirapine × 12 weeks + EBF Explanation: • Maternal viral load >1000 = high-risk transmission. • For high-risk infants: Dual prophylaxis (Zidovudine + Nevirapine) for 12 weeks.

questions.text: A college student found have meningitis. Prophylaxis to household contacts is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rifampicin Close contacts of a meningococcal meningitis case need chemoprophylaxis. Rifampicin is the drug of choice (600 mg BID for 2 days). Alternatives: Ciprofloxacin or Ceftriaxone in pregnancy. Penicillin treats the infection, not for prophylaxis.

questions.text: No siphon tube, larvae lie parallel to surface. Has one hair on body?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) – Anopheles Explanation

questions.text: The procedure is done for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The given pic shows ICRS/INTACS (Intra corneal ring segments) made of PMMA material and inserted in stroma of cornea to stabalize keratoconus
It is a type of refractive surgery as well

questions.text: A child came with bloody diarrhoea after consumption milk. Gram negative rods present. Choose the appropriate causative agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Campylobacter jejuni C. jejuni causes bloody diarrhea, often following undercooked poultry or contaminated milk. It's a curved Gram-negative rod, grows at 42°C, and is oxidase positive. Other choices are less likely: C. perfringens causes toxin-mediated diarrhea, Vibrio is usually associated with seafood.

questions.text: Identity the slowly growing painless lesion in 15 year old for past 1 decade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dermoid: Most common benign orbital tumour in child
Choristoma: normal tissue (Contain ectodermal and mesodermal origin such as hair follicles, sebaceous and sweat glands, ectopic lacrimal gland and cartilage) in abnormal place.
Orbital dermoid are mostly located superotemporal in orbit.
Often associated with other congenital ocular and systemic abnormalities such as oculoauriculovertebral dysplasia (Goldenhar syndrome), Duane's syndrome, coloboma of the upper lid, and lacrimal stenosis

questions.text: Identify the lesion in an old patient with decreased vision?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

There is deposition of grey dandruff- like material  in pseudoexfoliation syndrome
Here the material is seen over lens
If in the trabecular meshwork, it causes open angle glaucoma.  Later the iris can be pulled upwards (closed angle). It is seen in old age. It is most common secondary glaucoma.

choices.text: Providing fresh surface water for drinking
Adding alum and lime to his water

questions.text: In Chittur district of Andhra Pradesh, a person was found to have a knee deformity involving outward deviation of both the knees . He was found to have osteoporosis. Which of the following interventions will not be helpful for him ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fluoride supplementation Explanation: • Chittur is endemic for fluorosis (from groundwater). • Signs like genu valgum (knock knees), osteoporosis suggest skeletal fluorosis. • So fluoride supplementation is contraindicated. • Other options like changing source, adding alum/lime, and surface water help reduce fluoride intake.

questions.text: A female patient presents with urethritis and arthritis. Gonococcal infection is suspected. Due to deficiency in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) C5–C9 deficiency Deficiency of terminal complement components (MAC complex) increases susceptibility to Neisseria infections—especially N. gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis. C5-C9 form membrane attack complex responsible for killing Gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: Recommend cholesterol level to prevent coronary heart disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dietary cholesterol intake should be <300 mg/day, but not more than 100 mg per 1000 kcal.

questions.text: District survey report says due to new screening method, 5-year survival of breast cancer increased. But autopsy surveys revealed that there was no change in mortality. What type of bias?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) – Lead time bias Explanation Lead time bias: Even after early diagnosis and early treatment there is no improvement in prognosis.

questions.text:
A student was asked to pick the right boxes for deflouridation from the available boxes : 
A-Alum 
B-gypsum 
C- charcol 
D-lime Options :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A and D Explanation: • Alum + Lime = Nalgonda technique for defluoridation. • Charcoal does NOT remove fluoride. • Gypsum is not used for defluoridation.

questions.text: Young girl presented with vesicles around mouth and trigeminal neuralgia. Tzanck smear shows multinucleate giant cells and intranuclear inclusions.What is the causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) HSV HSV-1 typically causes cold sores around the mouth and can reactivate in trigeminal ganglion. Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells and Cowdry A inclusions. CMV shows owl's eye inclusions; EBV does not cause vesicles.

questions.text: 20 y/o patient developed fever and neck rigidity with hypotension. H/o skin rash present. Succumbed to death in the hospital. Gross image of brain given after autopsy. Choose the Causative agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neisseria meningitidis Rapid-onset meningitis with petechial/purpuric rash, hypotension, and death is classic for meningococcemia. Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome). N. meningitidis is Gram-negative diplococcus, oxidase positive, and ferments glucose and maltose. Autopsy macroscopically - - The leptomeninges (pia mater and arachnoid) covering the brain appear cloudy or opaque due to the presence of pus and inflammatory exudate.

questions.text: IFA dose 10 to 19 years as per WIFS:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 60 mg + 500 µg Explanation: • WIFS (Weekly Iron and Folic Supplementation) provides: 60 mg elemental iron 500 µg folic acid Once a week for adolescents 10–19 years.

questions.text: A patient came with the h/o swelling of foot, multiple sinuses and discharging black granules as shown in the image. What will be seen on microscopy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Septate hyphae This is eumycetoma, characterized by painless swelling, discharging sinuses, and black granules. Common agent is Madurella. Microscopy shows septate hyphae..

questions.text: What is used to measure the degree of objective and target achievement and asses the quality of results in a program?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) – Evaluation Explanation Evaluation refers to the systematic process of assessing what you do and how you do it to arrive at a judgement about the 'worth, merit or value' of something.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl child came with her mother with the complaints of perianal itching and h/o worm around anus. Microscopy shown in the image. Choose the correct organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Enterobius vermicularis The classical symptom of perianal itching, especially at night, in a child is pathognomonic for Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm). The eggs are flattened on one side and are seen in the perianal region using the Scotch tape test. Transmission occurs via fecal-oral route, especially in crowded environments like schools.

questions.text: A patient admitted with meningitis. Choose the test to identify organisms on syndromic basis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Multiplex PCR Multiplex PCR can detect multiple pathogens from one sample in a syndromic approach. Rapid, sensitive, and detects bacteria, viruses, fungi from CSF in suspected meningitis. Conventional PCR targets single pathogen, nested PCR increases sensitivity, RFLP is for typing.

questions.text: A patient admitted with cough & Sputum. BAL microscopy reveals a fungi showing septate hyphae with dichotomous branching. Choose the appropriate agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aspergillus Aspergillus spp. show acute-angle (45°), septate, dichotomously branching hyphae in tissue (especially in BAL or biopsy). It causes invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in immunocompromised, or aspergilloma in pre-existing cavities. Mucor has broad, ribbon-like non-septate hyphae.

questions.text: All 4 VVM stages given (IMAGES). Which will you use in your clinic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1 and 2 Explanation: • Only VVM Stage 1 and 2 indicates the vaccine is potent and safe to use. • Stages 3–4 indicate increasing heat exposure; discard.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with bullous keratopathy with guttata in other eye. This is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fuch’s dystrophy is bilateral, noninflammatory, progressive loss of corneal endothelium
Commonly in females

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the condition in the given image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is prone to eczema and hyperpigmentation The image displays a severe case of varicose veins, which is a sign of chronic venous insufficiency. This condition occurs when the valves in the veins malfunction, leading to blood pooling and increased pressure in the lower extremities. Over time, this chronic venous hypertension causes fluid and blood components to leak into the surrounding tissues, leading to skin changes such as venous eczema, which is a dry, itchy rash, and hyperpigmentation, where the skin becomes darker due to the deposition of hemosiderin (an iron-containing pigment from red blood cells). These skin changes are characteristic of advanced stages of the disease, as shown in the image.

In an unresponsive child with suspected foreign body aspiration:

Key features of Paget's disease: • Increased hat size ? due to skull thickening • Bone pain and deformities • Warmth over bones ? due to increased vascularity in affected areas • Lytic lesions (early stage), mixed lytic-sclerotic (later) • Commonly affects elderly men

Explanation:
Needle cricothyroidotomy is a temporary emergency airway procedure used in “can’t intubate, can’t oxygenate (CICO)” situations.
• It involves inserting a large-bore cannula (e.g., 14G) through the cricothyroid membrane to allow oxygenation via jet insufflation.
• It does not allow adequate ventilation or CO? elimination for long durations.

questions.text: What is the true about for the procedure shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Done in circumferential burns The image shows a simulated medical procedure likely representing escharotomy, which is performed in cases of circumferential burns. In deep burns, the inelastic burnt skin (eschar) can constrict underlying tissues. In circumferential limb or chest burns, this constriction can impair circulation or restrict breathing. An escharotomy involves making incisions through the eschar to relieve pressure, restore blood flow, and prevent complications like compartment syndrome. This is a life-saving emergency intervention, not primarily for cosmetic or healing purposes.

questions.text: A patient comes with painful swollen fingers with the following image, what is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Wet gangrene The image shows a swollen, discolored hand and fingers, with pus and a foul odor (as suggested by the clinical context of painful swelling and the appearance of the wound). Wet gangrene is characterized by tissue death caused by an infection, often with an underlying arterial or venous insufficiency. The presence of bacterial infection leads to liquefaction of the tissue, resulting in the edematous, blistered, and foul-smelling appearance seen in the image. . The affected area is typically swollen, moist, and appears purple-black. This is in contrast to dry gangrene, which is mummified and dry.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child comes with progressive phimosis. What is the white-sclerotic lesion seen on the penis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) BXO The clinical presentation of progressive phimosis in an 8-year-old child, the correct answer is A. BXO, which stands for Balanitis Xerotica Obliterans. This condition is a chronic, inflammatory, and progressive skin disease that primarily affects the glans penis and prepuce. BXO is characterized by the presence of white, sclerotic (hardened), and atrophic (thinned) plaques, which can be clearly seen in the image around the urethral meatus. This sclerotic tissue leads to the progressive narrowing of the preputial opening, causing phimosis. Over time, BXO can also lead to meatal stenosis, where the urethral opening itself narrows, as seen in the image. The progressive nature of the condition and the visible white, sclerotic lesion are classic signs of BXO.

questions.text: Based on the given image, which type of bile duct injury is shown according to the Strasberg classification?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Type A The image represents a Strasberg Type A bile duct injury. In this type, there is a leak from a minor bile duct without major disruption of the biliary tree continuity. Typically, this occurs from the cystic duct stump or small ducts in the liver bed (ducts of Luschka) after cholecystectomy. In the diagram, the leak is shown from a small duct, with the main hepatic and common bile ducts remaining intact, which matches the description of Type A injury.

questions.text: What is the type of anal fistula, seen in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Intersphincteric The fistula shown in the image is an Intersphincteric fistula. In this type, the tract passes between the internal and external anal sphincters and opens externally near the anal verge. It is the most common type of anal fistula (about 70% of cases). The internal opening is usually at the dentate line, and the fistula tract lies in the intersphincteric space without crossing the external sphincter muscle. This path is visible in the diagram where the tract (marked A) runs in the space between the internal and external sphincters before reaching the skin.

questions.text: What is the stage of CA Breast in the given image?

The image clearly shows these features: widespread redness and a dimpled, thickened appearance of the breast skin. T4d staging is based on these clinical findings alone, regardless of the tumor size or the involvement of the chest wall.

questions.text: Indentify the manouver shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Manoeuvres for Breech Vaginal Delivery 1. Delivery of the Buttocks and Legs • Pinard Manoeuvre: • Used to deliver extended legs in a breech presentation. • The practitioner gently flexes and abducts the thigh to bring the leg down, enabling delivery. 2. Delivery of the Trunk • Allow the trunk to deliver spontaneously up to the level of the scapula while supporting the baby. • Avoid traction to prevent overstretching of the spine or brachial plexus injuries. 3. Delivery of the Arms • Lovset Manoeuvre: • Used to deliver the arms when they are extended or above the head. • Rotate the baby gently by holding the hips to bring one shoulder and arm into the anterior-posterior plane. • Sweep the arm down across the chest to deliver it. • Repeat on the other side. 4. Delivery of the Head • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit Manoeuvre: • The baby is supported on the practitioner’s forearm with two fingers of one hand placed in the baby’s mouth (to flex the head). • The other hand applies gentle pressure on the baby’s occiput to assist in head flexion and delivery. • Burns-Marshall Manoeuvre: • Used when the baby’s head is at the perineum. • Hold the baby by the ankles, allow the body to hang until the nape of the neck is visible, and gently deliver the head. • Forceps Application: • Piper forceps can be used to assist in delivering the after-coming head in certain situations. 5. Other Specific Manoeuvres • Bracht Manoeuvre: • Used when the baby is delivered up to the umbilicus. • The baby’s body is lifted over the mother’s abdomen, using uterine pressure to assist in head delivery. ergency cesarean delivery if complications arise. Proper use of these maneuvers ensures a safe and controlled breech vaginal delivery.

questions.text: Which sign is cervical softening in pregnancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Goodell sign 1. Hegar’s Sign: • Definition: Softening of the lower uterine segment (isthmus) felt during a pelvic examination. • Significance: • Typically occurs around the 6th week of pregnancy. • Hegar’s sign is an early indicator of pregnancy and is often one of the first physical changes noted. • This sign is helpful in confirming early pregnancy, particularly in primigravid (first-time pregnant) women. 2. Goodell’s Sign: • Definition: Softening of the cervix due to increased blood flow and hormonal changes. • Significance: • This sign is often noticeable by the 6th week of pregnancy. • The cervix becomes softer, more vascular, and bluish in color (due to increased blood flow), which is a result of hormonal changes such as increased estrogen. • Goodell’s sign is used as a positive indicator of pregnancy and is more evident after fertilization and early gestation. 3. Osiander’s Sign: • Definition: Increased vascularity of the vaginal walls and cervix, making them appear more purple or cyanotic. • Significance: • This sign is typically visible around the 8th week of pregnancy. • Caused by increased blood flow due to the effects of hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. • It may be detected during a pelvic examination, where the vaginal mucosa and cervix appear congested and purplish, indicating early pregnancy. 4. Palmer’s Sign: • Definition: A pulsation felt in the lateral fornix of the vagina, often during a vaginal examination. • Significance: • The sign is caused by the increased blood flow to the pelvic area during pregnancy, leading to the pulsation of the uterine arteries. • It is an early sign of pregnancy, typically noticeable from around 8-10 weeks of gestation. • This sign is sometimes used as a confirmation of pregnancy, but it is not as commonly assessed today as other signs.

questions.text: Order of repair of episiotomy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mucosa muscle skin Anatomical order for episiotomy repair is: 1. Vaginal mucosa, 2. Perineal muscles, and 3. Skin. This sequence ensures anatomical alignment, proper healing, and minimization of complications such as infection, hematoma, or wound dehiscence. The repair begins with continuous suturing of the vaginal mucosa to restore the vaginal wall and prevent dead space. Then, the underlying perineal muscles (including the transverse perineal and bulbocavernosus muscles) are approximated to restore perineal body strength and support. Finally, the skin is closed, usually with interrupted or subcuticular sutures, to restore the external appearance and barrier. Proper layer-by-layer repair is critical to: Reduce bleeding, Restore anatomy, Prevent dyspareunia, Promote faster recovery.

choices.text: Continue NST for up to 40 mins

questions.text: A lady has come at 36 weeks with reduced fetal movement NST shows one acceleration in 20min what is to be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Continue NST for up to 40 mins A Non-Stress Test (NST) assesses fetal well-being by evaluating fetal heart rate (FHR) patterns in relation to fetal movements. A reactive NST (normal) in a term pregnancy is defined as at least two accelerations of fetal heart rate (15 bpm above baseline lasting 15 seconds) within 20 minutes. However, sometimes fetuses may be in a sleep cycle, which can last up to 40 minutes. Therefore, if only one acceleration is seen in the initial 20 minutes, the correct next step is to continue monitoring for up to 40 minutes to allow the fetus time to wake up and demonstrate reactivity. This avoids unnecessary interventions and is part of the standard protocol for NST interpretation.

questions.text: Loading dose of mgso4 as per Pritchard regimen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 14 gm The Pritchard regimen is a widely used protocol for administering magnesium sulfate (MgSO?) in the management of eclampsia and severe preeclampsia to prevent or control seizures. As per this regimen, the loading dose totals 14 grams, given in two parts: 4 g IV (intravenous) of 20% MgSO? solution is given slowly over 5–10 minutes 10 g IM (intramuscular) of 50% MgSO? solution is given, 5 g in each buttock, using a deep intramuscular injection with lignocaine to reduce pain. This regimen ensures rapid attainment of therapeutic serum magnesium levels and effective seizure prophylaxis. The Pritchard regimen is especially preferred in resource-limited settings, as it does not rely heavily on serum level monitoring but focuses on clinical monitoring for toxicity (e.g., reflexes, urine output, respiratory rate).

questions.text: Persistent op/face to pubes delivery is seen in which type of pelvis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The question asks about the type of pelvis most commonly associated with persistent occiput posterior (OP) or face to pubes delivery.

C. Anthropoid pelvis is the correct answer.

Anthropoid Pelvis Characteristics: An anthropoid pelvis is characterized by an anteroposterior diameter that is greater than its transverse diameter at the inlet. The inlet is oval-shaped, resembling that of an ape (hence "anthropoid"). The side walls are often convergent, and the sacrum is long and straight.
Impact on Fetal Rotation: Due to its long anteroposterior diameter and relatively narrow transverse diameter, the anthropoid pelvis tends to favor the fetal head entering the pelvis in an anteroposterior (occiput anterior or occiput posterior) position and persisting in these positions, often with a reduced tendency for internal rotation.
Persistent OP and Face to Pubes: When the fetal head enters the anthropoid pelvis in the occiput posterior (OP) position, the long anteroposterior diameter encourages it to remain in that orientation. Spontaneous rotation to an occiput anterior (OA) position is less common or more difficult. This can lead to a "persistent OP" presentation. If the head extends (rather than flexes) in this position, it can result in a "face to pubes" delivery, where the face presents under the pubic symphysis, which is a rare but possible outcome of persistent OP, particularly in an anthropoid pelvis.
A. Android pelvis is incorrect. An android pelvis is heart-shaped at the inlet, with a prominent sacrum and convergent side walls. It is associated with a higher incidence of deep transverse arrest, not typically persistent OP or face to pubes.

B. Gynecoid pelvis is incorrect. A gynecoid pelvis is the most common and ideal female pelvic shape, with a rounded or slightly oval inlet and well-proportioned diameters. It favors a well-flexed occiput anterior presentation and efficient rotation, making persistent OP or face to pubes less likely.

D. Platypelloid pelvis is incorrect. A platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a very wide transverse diameter and a very short anteroposterior diameter (flattened). It favors a transverse lie at the inlet and can lead to a deep transverse arrest or arrest at the inlet, but not typically persistent OP or face to pubes delivery.

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cotrolled cord traction The image depicts the controlled cord traction (CCT) method, a key component of the active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). In this technique, one hand applies steady traction on the umbilical cord while the other hand provides counter-pressure on the uterus through the abdomen to prevent uterine inversion. This helps in the safe delivery of the placenta once signs of placental separation appear. CCT reduces the duration of the third stage of labor and minimizes the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), making it a critical intervention in obstetric practice. The key identifying features in the image are: One hand pulling the cord. The other hand pushing against the uterus through the abdominal wall. An open uterus with the placenta visibly separated.

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lovset The image illustrates the Lovset maneuver, which is employed during assisted breech delivery when there is difficulty in delivering the fetal arms. In this technique, the fetus is gently held by the hips and rotated 180 degrees to bring the posterior shoulder anterior. This rotation facilitates the delivery of one arm under the symphysis pubis. Then the fetus is rotated in the opposite direction to deliver the second arm. The maneuver is especially helpful in breech deliveries when the arms are extended or not descending naturally. The image shows the rotation of the fetus and controlled handling at the level of the pelvis, both hallmark steps of Lovset’s maneuver

questions.text: 35 year old lady with FSH 50 IU raised LH 36and AMH less than 0.5 what is diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Primary ovarian insufficiency Primary Ovarian Insufficiency (POI), also known as premature ovarian failure, is defined as loss of ovarian function before the age of 40. The hallmark laboratory findings include markedly elevated gonadotropins (FSH > 40 IU/L and elevated LH) along with low anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) and low estradiol, reflecting diminished ovarian reserve. In this case, the woman is only 35 years old but has very high FSH (50 IU/L), high LH (36 IU/L), and AMH < 0.5, all of which strongly support a diagnosis of POI. AMH is a direct marker of the ovarian reserve, and levels < 1.0 ng/mL suggest poor ovarian reserve; <0.5 ng/mL is severely low. POI can be idiopathic or associated with autoimmune, genetic, or iatrogenic causes (e.g., chemotherapy, radiation). Clinically, these women may present with amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, infertility, or menopausal symptoms such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness.

questions.text: Woman with 28 day regular cycle on day 21 -25 what is status of hormones
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) High estrogen and progesterone and low fsh and lh In a normal 28-day menstrual cycle, day 21–25 corresponds to the mid to late luteal phase. This phase follows ovulation (which typically occurs around day 14) and is characterized by the activity of the corpus luteum, which secretes high levels of progesterone and moderate levels of estrogen. These hormones prepare the endometrium for potential implantation. The elevated levels of estrogen and progesterone exert negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary, thereby suppressing FSH and LH secretion. Hence, during this phase, FSH and LH are low, while estrogen and progesterone are elevated.

questions.text: Identify, the index finger is missing
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Amniotic band syndrome Amniotic Band Syndrome (ABS) is a congenital disorder caused by fibrous strands from the ruptured amniotic sac that entangle fetal parts, typically limbs, digits, or face, leading to constriction rings, amputations, or deformities. The absence of a digit, such as the index finger, in an otherwise structurally normal limb is a classic presentation. These defects are often asymmetric and not associated with genetic abnormalities. The severity depends on the timing and location of amniotic rupture. ABS can be diagnosed postnatally by observing amputated or constricted limbs, and sometimes prenatally via ultrasound.

choices.text: Decrease release of gnrh from hypothalamus

questions.text: High prolactin causes amenorrhea because
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Decrease release of gnrh from hypothalamus Hyperprolactinemia leads to amenorrhea primarily by suppressing the hypothalamic release of GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone). Prolactin acts at the hypothalamic level, inhibiting GnRH secretion, which in turn causes reduced pulsatile secretion of LH and FSH from the anterior pituitary. These gonadotropins are essential for follicular development and ovulation. Their suppression results in anovulation and amenorrhea. This mechanism is especially seen in conditions like prolactinomas or during lactation, when prolactin levels are physiologically high.

questions.text: Sequence of manoeuvers in shoulder dystocia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mc Robert, rubin, gaskin, zavanelli Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency where the fetal anterior shoulder gets stuck behind the maternal pubic symphysis after the head is delivered. Management must be systematic and escalating, starting from least invasive to more invasive steps. The recommended sequence is: McRoberts Maneuver – This is the first-line intervention. It involves hyperflexion and abduction of the mother’s hips to straighten the sacrum and rotate the pelvis, which can relieve up to 40% of cases. Gaskin Maneuver – If McRoberts fails, this involves placing the mother in the all-fours (hands and knees) position, which can help rotate the baby and relieve impaction. Rubin Maneuver – An internal maneuver that involves applying pressure to the posterior aspect of the anterior fetal shoulder to rotate it into the oblique diameter. Zavanelli Maneuver – This is a last resort when all other maneuvers fail. It involves replacing the fetal head into the vagina followed by emergency cesarean section. This stepwise approach is critical to reduce fetal hypoxia, brachial plexus injury, and other complications.

questions.text: 65 year old postmenopausal woman with BP 170/100 with blood stained vaginal discharge next step
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Do pelvic exam and send PAPS Postmenopausal bleeding or blood-stained discharge is considered abnormal and potentially serious, especially in women over 60, as it may be the first sign of genital tract malignancy, particularly cervical or endometrial cancer. The appropriate first step is a per vaginal examination to assess the source of bleeding, look for cervical lesions, atrophy, or growth, and to collect a Pap smear (PAPS) to evaluate for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma. Even if the discharge is minimal or intermittent, it must never be ignored in postmenopausal women. Early evaluation ensures timely diagnosis and treatment of malignancy, if present. The elevated blood pressure should also be addressed, but it does not delay the immediate gynecological evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: Lady is in labour 5 cm dilated vertex at develops cord prolapse, there is cord pulsation what is next step
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Buttock lift Push back head with retrograde bladder filling Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part, risking cord compression and fetal hypoxia. The presence of cord pulsations indicates that fetal circulation is still intact, and urgent action is needed to preserve it until definitive delivery (usually via cesarean section). The immediate next step is to relieve pressure on the cord to maintain blood flow. This includes: Buttock elevation (Trendelenburg or knee-chest position), Manual elevation of the presenting part (pushing the head off the cord), Filling the bladder retrograde with saline (about 500 mL) to elevate the presenting part, Avoiding manipulation of the cord, to prevent vasospasm. These temporary measures buy time and preserve fetal oxygenation while preparing for emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: 46 year old woman with irregular bleeding with endometrial thickness 16 mm nect step
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Endometrial biopsy In a perimenopausal woman (like this 46-year-old) with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) and endometrial thickness >4 mm, the next step is to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. An endometrial thickness of 16 mm is significantly increased and raises suspicion for endometrial pathology, especially in the setting of irregular bleeding. Therefore, the next appropriate investigation is an endometrial biopsy, which is a minimally invasive, office-based procedure that helps in diagnosing hyperplasia (with or without atypia) or endometrial cancer. Timely diagnosis is crucial for initiating appropriate treatment and avoiding progression to malignancy.
